intro: Triphysaria eriantha subsp. rosea, commonly known as the roseate sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and distinctive floral structures. The plant produces small, pink to rose-colored flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are typically alternate, ovate, and covered in fine pubescence, which helps reduce water loss in its harsh environment. Triphysaria eriantha subsp. rosea is adapted to sandy soils and thrives in full sun, making it a resilient species in desert ecosystems.
